en.description: Calculate your mutual fund XIRR (Extended Internal Rate of Return) with our advanced calculator. Perfect for investors with multiple transactions, SIP entries, and varying investment amounts. Get accurate time-weighted returns for your portfolio.
en.summary: Calculate XIRR returns on mutual fund investments accounting for transaction timing
en.introduction: XIRR (Extended Internal Rate of Return) is the most accurate way to measure your investment returns when you have irregular transactions or multiple SIP entries. Unlike simple CAGR, XIRR accounts for the timing of each transaction, giving you the true rate of return. Our calculator helps you understand your actual investment performance and compare it against benchmarks.
benefits: Calculates accurate time-weighted returns using XIRR method
Handles multiple irregular transactions and SIP entries
Accounts for timing of investments and withdrawals
Shows actual performance vs expected returns
Perfect for comparing different mutual funds
Helps identify best performing schemes in your portfolio
steps: Enter your investment amounts and transaction dates (all SIP entries)
Add any lumpsum investments with their respective dates
Enter current value or redemption amounts with dates
The calculator computes your XIRR percentage return
inputsExplained: Transaction Date: The exact date of investment, SIP entry, or redemption
Transaction Amount: Investment amount (positive) or redemption/current value (negative for exit)
Net Investment: Sum of all amounts invested over time
Current Value: Current portfolio value (or final redemption amount if scheme sold)
en.formulaExplanation: XIRR uses the Internal Rate of Return formula with daily compounding. It solves: NPV = 0 = Σ [Cash Flow / (1 + XIRR)^(days/365)]. Each transaction is weighted by how long money remained invested. This method is superior to CAGR when you have timing variations in investments - it gives you the actual annualized return your money earned regardless of when you invested.

seoContent.introduction: Know exactly how well your mutual fund investments are performing. XIRR (Extended Internal Rate of Return) measures your actual returns accounting for timing of investments and withdrawals. Whether you've been investing ₹5,000 monthly for 5 years or made multiple lumpsum investments, this calculator shows your true performance.
benefits: Calculate true XIRR accounting for investment timing
Measure returns better than simple percentage gains
Track multiple investments in same fund over time
Include additions and withdrawals in calculation
Understand effect of rupee-cost averaging on returns
howToUse: Add investment transaction: date, amount, type (buy/sell)
Enter current fund value and today's date
Compare with benchmark return (NIFTY 50, Sensex, Bond Index)
Review annual XIRR tracking vs goals
seoContent.formulaExplanation: XIRR uses Internal Rate of Return formula accounting for cash flows at different times. It finds the rate that makes NPV (Net Present Value) of all cash flows = 0. Example: Invested ₹10,000 in Jan 2020, ₹10,000 in Jan 2021, current value ₹25,000 in 2024 = 30% XIRR. Better than simple return (25,000-20,000)/20,000 = 25%) because it accounts for timing.
examples: SIP ₹5,000/month for 5 years (total ₹3 lakh), current value ₹4 lakh = ~15-18% XIRR
Lumpsum ₹10 lakh in Jan 2020, current value ₹18 lakh in 2024 = ~16% XIRR
Multiple investments: ₹5 lakh (2020), ₹8 lakh (2021), withdrawn ₹2 lakh (2022), current ₹15 lakh = XIRR calculation accounts for all timings
seoContent.whoShouldUse: SIP investors tracking portfolio performance, mutual fund investors with multiple transactions, those comparing fund performance against benchmarks, individuals evaluating advisor performance, anyone wanting to understand true investment returns vs simple percentage gains.
seoContent.importantNotes: XIRR is superior to CAGR for measuring actual investment performance. Benchmark comparison: Equity funds typically return 10-15% XIRR, Balanced: 8-12%, Debt: 6-8%. Consider expense ratio (1-2% annually) when interpreting XIRR vs benchmark. Tax impact: XIRR shown as pre-tax; actual returns after 20% TCS/capital gains tax will be lower.

faqs.question: What's the difference between XIRR and CAGR?
faqs.answer: CAGR is simple annualized return. XIRR accounts for when each investment was made. SIP ₹5,000/month for 5 years: CAGR ignores timing (wrong), XIRR accounts for it (correct). Use XIRR for actual fund performance.

faqs.question: Should I switch funds if XIRR is below 12%?
faqs.answer: Not immediately. Consider: underperformance might be short-term (1-2 years). Check 3-5 year XIRR vs benchmark. High exit loads reduce returns. Switching incurs taxes. Review fund strategy before exiting.

faqs.question: Is 15% XIRR good?
faqs.answer: Very good! Equity funds average 10-12% long-term. 15% beats most advisors/funds. Debt funds at 7-8% are good. Mixed above benchmark by 2-3% = good performance.

faqs.question: How often should I check XIRR?
faqs.answer: Quarterly check is fine (don't obsess). Annual review recommended. During market crashes, checking daily is counter-productive. Focus on 3-5 year XIRR, not quarterly volatility.

faqs.question: Can XIRR be negative?
faqs.answer: Yes, if current value < total invested. Market correction can cause negative XIRR short-term. Stay invested - historically all corrections reverse. Panic selling locks in losses.
